body_html:
Dear Gunan, Thanks allot for your response. That's a great suggestion, but i need to learn fast because i will need to work on a real project with real pictures and try to implement a classification according to project requirements. You think CPU is good enough for that? Note that i have an Alienware laptop with Nvidia 770M. Again, thanks allot for your input :) Sincerely, Maher A. Nadar
…
On Fri, Mar 3, 2017 at 11:52 PM, gunan ***@***.***> wrote: If you are a beginner on linux, we recommend starting with the command @MikeTam1021 <https://github.com/MikeTam1021> suggested. Since GPU version requires a lot of non-trivial installation of CUDA, cuDNN, and manipulation of environment variables, you should definitely start with the CPU version. If you are using ubuntu 14.04, you may need to run the pip install command with the URL as follows. pip install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/tensorflow-1.0.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl — You are receiving this because you authored the thread. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#8056 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AY86zbRKafxVGZ0gd9n84rRhh4Ic8Fsoks5riJmxgaJpZM4MSbbw> .
body_text:
Dear Gunan,

Thanks allot for your response. That's a great suggestion, but i need to
learn fast because i will need to work on a real project with real pictures
and try to implement a classification according to project requirements.

You think CPU is good enough for that? Note that i have an Alienware laptop
with Nvidia 770M.

Again, thanks allot for your input :)

Sincerely,

Maher A. Nadar
…
On Fri, Mar 3, 2017 at 11:52 PM, gunan ***@***.***> wrote:
 If you are a beginner on linux, we recommend starting with the command
 @MikeTam1021 <https://github.com/MikeTam1021> suggested. Since GPU
 version requires a lot of non-trivial installation of CUDA, cuDNN, and
 manipulation of environment variables, you should definitely start with the
 CPU version.

 If you are using ubuntu 14.04, you may need to run the pip install command
 with the URL as follows.

 pip install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/tensorflow-1.0.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl

 —
 You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#8056 (comment)>,
 or mute the thread
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AY86zbRKafxVGZ0gd9n84rRhh4Ic8Fsoks5riJmxgaJpZM4MSbbw>
 .
body:
Dear Gunan,

Thanks allot for your response. That's a great suggestion, but i need to
learn fast because i will need to work on a real project with real pictures
and try to implement a classification according to project requirements.

You think CPU is good enough for that? Note that i have an Alienware laptop
with Nvidia 770M.

Again, thanks allot for your input :)

Sincerely,

Maher A. Nadar

On Fri, Mar 3, 2017 at 11:52 PM, gunan <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> If you are a beginner on linux, we recommend starting with the command
> @MikeTam1021 <https://github.com/MikeTam1021> suggested. Since GPU
> version requires a lot of non-trivial installation of CUDA, cuDNN, and
> manipulation of environment variables, you should definitely start with the
> CPU version.
>
> If you are using ubuntu 14.04, you may need to run the pip install command
> with the URL as follows.
>
> pip install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/tensorflow-1.0.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/8056#issuecomment-284092573>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AY86zbRKafxVGZ0gd9n84rRhh4Ic8Fsoks5riJmxgaJpZM4MSbbw>
> .
>
